title: Genre: Epistle and Didactic Literature
objective: Interpret letters with attention to argument structure, purpose, and paraenesis

required_passages.text: You were dead in trespasses and sins, walking according to this age. But God, rich in mercy, made us alive with Christ, raised us, and seated us with Him by grace. Salvation is by grace through faith, not by works, and believers are created in Christ Jesus for good works prepared beforehand.

segments.audio_script: This is lesson eleven. We study epistles, their structure, and rhetorical aims.

Listen to the passage. Ephesians 2:1-10. You were dead in trespasses and sins, walking according to this age. But God, rich in mercy, made us alive with Christ, raised us, and seated us with Him by grace. Salvation is by grace through faith, not by works, and believers are created in Christ Jesus for good works prepared beforehand. Now identify the argument flow from human condition to divine action to resulting purpose.
Letters address specific situations and contain doctrinal teaching plus practical application. Recognize occasional versus universal instruction.
Ask which statements are prescriptive for all churches and which respond to local problems. Consider author's tone and goals.
Key skill: distinguish situational advice from timeless doctrine through textual and contextual cues.
What two parts often appear in epistles?
This completes lesson eleven. Next lesson integrates genre sensitivity into theological reading.

vocabulary.definition: Ethical exhortation or practical instruction commonly found in letters

study_notes: Pay attention to how authors move from doctrine to duty; proper application respects original intent.
